## Data Science Specialization - course 2
  
## Objective  
It calculates the average contamination of sulfate or nitrate particles, based on the data obtained in 332 locations in the USA, each site has generated a monitoring file.  
  
Description  
Each file contains several records, each record contains 4 variables:
• Date: date of observation in format YYYY-MM-DD (year-month-day)
• sulfate: the level of PM sulfate in the air at that date (measured in micrograms per cubic meter)
• nitrate: the level of PM nitrate in the air at that date (measured in micrograms per cubic meter)
• Id: file handle.    
  
Note. Note that many records do not contain data (NA) this is common in monitoring data.    
  
## Homework 1  
  
Develop a function to calculate the average contaminant by sulfate or nitrate, passing three parameters:  
Parameter 1 = the directory where the files are.  
Parameter 2 = the pollutant to be calculated; sulfate or nitrate.  
Parametro3 = the list of files to process.  
Development process:  
  
Setting up a working environment.  
  
1. We create a folder.  
  
mkdir XXXXX  
cd XXXX  
  
2. We download the data to be processed.  
  
```{r, echo=TRUE}

url = "https://d396qusza40orc.cloudfront.net/rprog%2Fdata%2Fspecdata.zip"
```

Comments:  
The zip file we downloaded we put a random name (urlFileData.zip), we can put the same name, but in this case we have renamed it.

3. We scanned the downloaded content.

XXXXX/data

XXXXX/data/specdata/001.csv  
XXXXX/data/specdata/002.csv

4. We scanned the contents of the files. Let's take as an example the reading of the first file.  
  
```{r, echo=TRUE}  
# load the contents of the file into the variable file.temp.
file.temp = read.csv(file="data/specdata/001.csv", header = TRUE, sep = ",")
head(file.temp)

```
  
We check that the variables are; Date, sulfate, nitrate, and ID  
We also check that there is no data for some NA dates.  
  
5. Create to the Algorithm to determine the level of contamination.  
-Load the selected file.  
-filter by a type of pollutant (sulfate or nitrate) to obtain only useful data, this data we store them in a vector.  
This vector will be incremented by each processed file.  
  
In the end, we calculate the mean with the data stored in the vector.  
  
Function created:   
  
```{r, echo=TRUE}  
pollutantmean <- function(path.files, pollutant, id = 0) {
  
  #We store all file names
  list.filenames <- list.files(path.files, pattern="*.csv")
  
  #numercia list that stores all values, useful to determine the median
  list.values <- numeric()
  
  #this validation is useful if you enter as parameter id = 0
  if(length(id) == 1){
    if(id == 0){
      id = 332
    }
  }
  
  for(i in c(id) ) {
    
    #file name processing
    filename <- paste(path.files, list.filenames[i], sep = "/")
    
    #load the file contents
    df.File <- read.csv(filename, head=TRUE, sep=",")
    
    #filter by sulfate or nitrate
    if(pollutant == "sulfate"){
      valores <- df.File$sulfate[!is.na(df.File$sulfate)]
    }
    else{
      valores <- df.File$nitrate[!is.na(df.File$nitrate)]
    }
    
    #It contains all values for each interaction
    list.values <- append(list.values, valores)
  }
  
  #calculation of the mean
  return(mean(list.values))
}

```
  
We execute the function to calculate the average summing all the files from 1 to the last 332.  
```{r, echo=TRUE}  
#pollutantmean ("data/specdata", "sulfate", 1:332)
# example
pollutantmean ("data/specdata", "sulfate", 1:10)

```
  
## Homework 2  
  
Write a function that reads a directory full of files and reports the number of completely observed cases in each data file for sulfates and nitrates.  
  
Make a sum for each day observed of the variables.  
  
```{r, echo=TRUE}  
complete  <- function(path.files, id) {
  
  #We store all file names
  list.filenames <- list.files(path.files, pattern="*.csv")
  
  id.file <- integer()
  num.filas1 <- integer()
  num.filas2 <- integer()
  
  for(i in c(id) ) {
    
    #file name processing
    filename <- paste(path.files, list.filenames[i], sep = "/")
    
    #load the file contents
    df.File <- read.csv(filename, head=TRUE, sep=",")
    
    filas1 <- length(df.File$sulfate[!is.na(df.File$sulfate)])
    filas2 <- length(df.File$nitrate[!is.na(df.File$nitrate)])
    
    id.file <- append(id.file, i)
    num.filas1 <- append(num.filas1, filas1)
    num.filas2 <- append(num.filas2, filas2)
    
  }
  
  rspta <- data.frame(id.file , num.filas1, num.filas2)
  
  #rspta.names <- c("id", "nobs")
  colnames(rspta) <- c("id.file", "nobs.sulfate", "nobs.nitrate")
  
  rspta
  
}

# Example
tmp <- complete ("data/specdata", 1:10)
tmp

```


## Homework 3
  
Write a function that takes a directory of data files and a threshold for full cases and calculates the correlation between sulfate and nitrate for monitor locations where the number of cases completely.  
  
The correlation coefficient provides a measure of how two random variables are associated in a “sample”.  
  
```{r, echo=TRUE}

tmp.cor <- cor(tmp)
tmp.cor
plot(tmp$nobs.sulfate, tmp$nobs.nitrate)

```
  
  
The correlation between the two variables is strong, if one variable grows the other also grows.
